TopicTitle: Poll, the R.A.P.I.E.R, what do you think it needs

Articles.Content: So what do you all think? Personally i think it could do with a better top speed in atmosphere, perhaps 1400 m/s than the now 1200 m/s, as the real SABRE can go to mach 5, i feel the rapier needs to keep gaining power longer past when turbojets flameout to distinguish itself as a airbreathing engine against the turbojet. at the moment the rapiers airbreathing mode had less thrust and isp than the turbojet, the only advantage is that it peaks at a slightly higher speed. all i think it needs then, is a thrust increase, and a slight top speed increase, that would make it more viable than the turbojet for sstos IMO.
I think it's fine the way it is!
but dont you thing it could do with a biiit more speed than the turbojet? just 1400 m/s in atmo maybe?
Your speed is more a factor of your drag, you can always add more engines but if you're craft is draggy there's only so much that more power will do for you.

No, I think the turbojet should have more punch to it. To me it seems more like a game-balancing thing. Since the RAPIER has 2 modes and can work in space, why would you also make it faster than the turbojet? If it was, nobody would ever use the turbojet... Just like if the nuclear engine has the same thrust as a poodle, nobody would ever use a poodle...

But that's just my 0.02 m/s....

Well the turbojet would still be better up to mach3 , the rapiers just push to mach 4 they would still be the same other than that I guess. So turbojet would still be better for atmospheric craft due to better isp and thrust at lower mach number
Balance-wise I think it's ok. I'd actually reduce the thrust at mach 2-3 a little and maybe compensate with slightly less steep decline in performance at higher altitudes.

Given that the RAPIERs are, if anything, a bit overpowered, they certainly don't need a boost. One RAPIER is enough for most Mk2 ships, and dangerously overpowered (but fun!) for Mk1 planes. Four RAPIERs will easily handle a lumbering Mk3 monstrosity.

Stock is a bit draggier than FAR, but you can still get a good-sized Mk2 up to speed with only one or two engines if you build and fly it right.

As was hinted upthread, aircraft speed is mostly about drag rather than power. Power gets you off the ground, but you need streamlining for serious velocity. Once you really get moving, shaving a tiny percentage off your drag gets you as much benefit as doubling your engine thrust.

In thrust we trust, sure, but there are reasons why aircraft designers go to such extreme lengths to minimise drag.
